oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Thruway: Construction of the S Curve of Tappan Zee Bridge
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The snow sits on the completed bridge as the opening ceremony is about to begin. The final structure measures 16.013 feet long, just over three miles, and will be seven lanes wide. When the bridge opened in December 1955, it carried an average of 18,000 vehicles each way. On a clear day, the New York City skyline can be seen looking south along the Hudson River. Kathryn W. Burke, "Hudson River Bridges."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Thruway: Opening Ceremony
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Crawford, Dorothy Hand
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Crowds gathered on a cold December 15, 1955 for the official opening of the Tappan Zee Bridge. There are flags, a color guard, and a band. Cameramen stand atop cars. Many cars and a bus are in line in the eastbound lane, ready to drive across the bridge. The bridge is said to be named Tappan Zee after the Tappan tribe of Native Americans who once lived in the area - and for the Dutch zee, an open expanse of water. Later in 1994, the bridge would be renamed Governor Malcolm Wilson Tappan Zee Bridge in honor of the former governor.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Thruway: House Destruction
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Much of the Village of South Nyack had to be destroyed when the NYS Thruway was built. The 'vault' on the right side of this photograph was part of the village hall where records were stored. The rubble in the foreground forms the remains of the building which housed the village government. The house in the background was on Willow Avenue and belonged to the Hackett family. It was about 100 years old but the family could not afford the costs of moving and renovating the structure. (The Thruway Authority gave payments for the houses but not for the costs of saving and moving them.)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ivanhoe Inn 1906
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A copy of a Rockland Review article in which the Ivanhoe Inn is described as the place where Ben Hecht and Charles McArthur wrote the play, "Front Page." Village historian Jean Pardo identifies that as an error. The inn which the playwrights rented for an entire summer was the Tappan Zee Inn, the former Female Institute.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Main and Broadway, Nyack, NY
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A wide angle view of the intersection of Main Street and Broadway in Nyack. Main Street looking east is in the center; South Broadway is on the left and North Broadway on the right. Several pedestrians, horses-and-carriages, and automobiles are captured on the image. On the northeast corner is the Rockland County Trust (Trachtenberg ) building. On the northwest corner is the Nyack Shoe Shine Parlor. To its right are Nyack Express and a barber shop. Across the street is a confectionery. Nyack, N. Y. is printed across the center sky. On the back are postage instructions, "One cent without writing, Two cents with writing."
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Streets; Panoramic photographs
Rockland County Trust Company
Business & Industry; Architecture;
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: Postcard; Black and white, 20.5 x 3.5 in. 3 copies, various sizes are in Oversize Box 9.
